newsitem.title: UK: Metals end jumpy LME mostly steady, off highs.
newsitem.headline: Metals end jumpy LME mostly steady, off highs.

text.p: Base metal markets were flighty during Thursday LME trading, with clear trends difficult to discern, and prices largely finished off their highs after a see-sawing session.

Traders said there was a feeling that some markets like copper and nickel were over-extended and ripe for a solid downside reaction. But with funds picking off price dips, there was little substance to declines.

So, during the session, nickel notched up a new nine-month high, zinc neared its recent two-year peak, while copper and aluminium showed signs of approaching Wednesday's high-points. However, the lack of follow-through at the highs eventually induced modest retreats.
"At the moment it is the funds that are holding things up -- we are not seeing anything physical," one trader said.

Copper was largely on the defensive, apart from spells of covering which foundered just above $2,400 with producers looking to lock in forward sales. There was also some lending of the spreads, although the premiums mostly held steady. Stocks on Friday are expected to register a decline, some said.
Last Thursday business was at $2,393 a tonne, up just $1 from the previous kerb, but well below the $2,412 peak.
Aluminium probed above the $1,660 level intermittently, but ran into profit-taking and speculative selling. Last trade was at $1,652, a $13 loss from the previous kerb.
Nickel prices flew around in their usual volatile fashion, at one point hitting fresh nine-month highs of $8,180 when buy-stops were triggered above $8,100, traders said.

Underpinning the market are flurries of fund interest, as well as the rumblings from Russia's Norilsk, where strike action is a possibility. But the thinness of the market was accentuated by late action, with prices easing back to close the kerb at $8,070, still up $20.
The zinc market showed signs at one stage of testing the recent two-year peak of $1,235 before prices hurriedly re-traced with copper. Last business was at $1,227, a $5 gain from Wednesday.
Meanwhile, Swiss commodity trader Glencore continued to strengthen its profile in the market by increasing its stake in France's Metaleurop.
Lead was mostly subdued throughout the session, until late covering helped raise values from overnight levels. By the end of the kerb the market was $10 higher at $675.
Tin conditions were patchy, with some fund interest and end-user enquiry circulating. Again, a late flurry of buying lifted prices to the day's high with last business at $5,880, up $39.
A quiet alloy market was largely stable, and traded last at an unchanged $1,550 a tonne.
